messages.content:
You are a professional academic reference prediction expert. Your task is to predict the most likely references for a given academic paper based on its title, abstract, and retrieved relevant papers.

RETRIEVER INTERFACE:
- Input: paper title + abstract
- Output: {top_r} retrieved papers with title and abstract
- Format: List of dictionaries with 'title' and 'abstract' fields

REQUIREMENTS:
1. Analyze the paper's title and abstract to understand its research area and focus
2. Consider the retrieved papers as potential references (when available)
3. Generate a list of predicted reference titles that would be most relevant and likely to be cited
4. Provide reasoning for each prediction to prevent hallucination
5. Output format: JSON object with "titles" array and "reasoning" string
6. Generate exactly 49 most relevant reference titles (this should be at least 40 to cover all evaluation metrics)
7. Ensure titles are realistic and appropriate for the research area
8. Consider citation patterns in the field
9. CRITICAL: Each title must be unique - never repeat the same title multiple times

EXAMPLE:
Input:
Title: "Question Type Classification Methods Comparison"
Abstract: "The paper presents a comparative study of state-of-the-art approaches for question classification task: Logistic Regression, Convolutional Neural Networks (CNN), Long Short-Term Memory Network (LSTM) and Quasi-Recurrent Neural Networks (QRNN). All models use pre-trained GLoVe word embeddings and trained on human-labeled data. The best accuracy is achieved using CNN model with five convolutional layers and various kernel sizes stacked in parallel, followed by one fully connected layer. The model reached 90.7% accuracy on TREC 10 test set."

Retrieved papers ({top_r}):
1. Title: Convolutional Neural Networks for Sentence Classification
   Abstract: We report on a series of experiments with convolutional neural networks trained on top of pre-trained word vectors for sentence-level classification tasks.

2. Title: Glove: Global vectors for word representation
   Abstract: We present a new global log-bilinear regression model that combines the advantages of the two major model families in the literature.

Output:
{
  "titles": [
    "Convolutional Neural Networks for Sentence Classification",
    "Glove: Global vectors for word representation",
    "Quasi-Recurrent Neural Networks",
    "A Comparative Study of Neural Network Models for Sentence Classification",
    "Deep lstm based feature mapping for query classification"
  ],
  "reasoning": "Based on the paper's focus on question classification using neural networks, I predict these references because: 1) CNN paper is directly relevant to the convolutional approach used; 2) GloVe embeddings are mentioned as pre-trained features; 3) QRNN is one of the compared methods; 4) Comparative study papers are common in this field; 5) LSTM-based query classification is closely related to question classification. Additional references cover related neural network architectures, NLP applications, deep learning methodologies, optimization techniques, and advanced neural network methods that would be relevant for this research area."
}

Return JSON object only.

Paper Title: Counting Small Induced Subgraphs: Hardness via Fourier Analysis Funded by the European Union (ERC, CountHom, 101077083). Views and opinions expressed are however those of the author(s) only and do not necessarily reflect those of the European Union or the European Research Council Executive Agency. Neither the European Union nor the granting authority can be held responsible for them.

Paper Abstract: Abstract For a fixed graph property Î¦Î¦\Phi and integer kâ‰¥1ğ‘˜1k\geq 1, the problem #â€‹IndSubâ€‹(Î¦,k)#IndSubÎ¦ğ‘˜\#\textnormal{{IndSub}}(\Phi,k) asks to count the induced kğ‘˜k-vertex subgraphs satisfying Î¦Î¦\Phi in an input graph GğºG. If Î¦Î¦\Phi is trivial on kğ‘˜k-vertex graphs (i.e., if Î¦Î¦\Phi contains either all or no kğ‘˜k-vertex graphs), this problem is trivial. Otherwise we prove, among other results: â€¢ If Î¦Î¦\Phi is edge-monotone (i.e., closed under deleting edges), then #â€‹IndSubâ€‹(Î¦,k)#IndSubÎ¦ğ‘˜\#\textnormal{{IndSub}}(\Phi,k) cannot be solved in time noâ€‹(k)superscriptğ‘›ğ‘œğ‘˜n^{o(k)} assuming ETH. This strengthens a result by DÃ¶ring, Marx and Wellnitz [STOC 2024] that only ruled out an exponent of oâ€‹(logâ¡k/logâ¡logâ¡k)ğ‘œğ‘˜ğ‘˜o(\sqrt{\log k}/\log\log k). Our results also hold when counting modulo fixed primes. â€¢ If there is some fixed Îµ>0ğœ€0\varepsilon>0 such that at most (2âˆ’Îµ)(k2)superscript2ğœ€binomialğ‘˜2(2-\varepsilon)^{\binom{k}{2}} graphs on kğ‘˜k vertices satisfy Î¦Î¦\Phi, then #â€‹IndSubâ€‹(Î¦,k)#IndSubÎ¦ğ‘˜\#\textnormal{{IndSub}}(\Phi,k) cannot be solved in time noâ€‹(k/logâ¡k)superscriptğ‘›ğ‘œğ‘˜ğ‘˜n^{o(k/\sqrt{\log k})} assuming ETH. Our results hold even when each of the graphs in Î¦Î¦\Phi may come with an arbitrary individual weight. This generalizes previous results for hereditary properties by Focke and Roth [SIAM J. Comput. 2024] up to a logâ¡kğ‘˜\sqrt{\log k} factor in the exponent of the lower bound. â€¢ If Î¦Î¦\Phi only depends on the number of edges, then #â€‹IndSubâ€‹(Î¦,k)#IndSubÎ¦ğ‘˜\#\textnormal{{IndSub}}(\Phi,k) cannot be solved in time noâ€‹(k)superscriptğ‘›ğ‘œğ‘˜n^{o(k)} assuming ETH. This improves on a lower bound by Roth, Schmitt and Wellnitz [FOCS 2020] that only ruled out an exponent of oâ€‹(k/logâ¡k)ğ‘œğ‘˜ğ‘˜o(k/\sqrt{\log k}). In all cases, we also obtain #W[1]-hardness if kğ‘˜k is part of the input and the problem is parameterized by kğ‘˜k. We also obtain lower bounds on the Weisfeiler-Leman dimension. Most importantly, our results follow from relatively straightforward Fourier analysis, as opposed to the nontrivial techniques from combinatorics, group theory, and simplicial topology used in previous papers. Our paper subsumes most of the known #W[1]-hardness results known in the area, often with tighter lower bounds under ETH.

{retrieved_text}

Generate exactly 49 most likely reference titles for this paper. Focus on papers that are directly related to the research topic, provide foundational background, present similar methodologies, or address related problems.

CRITICAL: Each title must appear exactly once. Do not repeat any title.

IMPORTANT: You must respond with ONLY valid JSON in this exact format:
{
    "titles": [
        "Reference Title 1",
        "Reference Title 2",
        "Reference Title 3",
        "Reference Title 4",
        "Reference Title 49"
    ],
    "reasoning": "Explain why you chose these specific references based on the paper's title, abstract, and retrieved papers. This helps prevent hallucination and ensures relevance."
}

Do not include any text before or after the JSON. Do not include authors, venues, or years - only the paper titles. The reasoning field is required to explain your prediction logic.

{
    "titles": [
        "Determinant versus permanent",
        "Counting subgraphs via homomorphisms",
        "On Weisfeiler-Leman invariance: Subgraph counts and related graph properties",
        "On the Weisfeiler-Leman dimension of fractional packing",
        "The difference between consecutive primes. II.",
        "The parity of set systems under random restrictions with applications to exponential time problems",
        "Polynomial bounds for the grid-minor theorem",
        "Tight lower bounds for certain parameterized np-hard problems",
        "Understanding the complexity of induced subgraph isomorphisms",
        "The simple, little and slow things count: on parameterized counting complexity",
        "Homomorphisms are a good basis for counting small subgraphs",
        "Complexity of counting subgraphs: Only the boundedness of the vertex-cover number counts",
        "Parameterized Algorithms",
        "Space time tradeoffs for graph properties",
        "Counting induced subgraphs: An algebraic approach to #W[1]-hardness",
        "Counting small induced subgraphs with edge-monotone properties",
        "On recognizing graphs by numbers of homomorphisms",
        "Asymptotic enumeration of Knsubscriptğ¾ğ‘›K_{n}-free graphs",
        "Parameterized Complexity Theory",
        "Counting small induced subgraphs with hereditary properties",
        "On the combinatorial power of the Weisfeiler-Lehman algorithm",
        "The Weisfeiler-Leman dimension of conjunctive queries",
        "Descriptive Complexity, Canonisation, and Definable Graph Structure Theory, volume 47 of Lecture Notes in Logic",
        "Recent advances on the graph isomorphism problem",
        "Which problems have strongly exponential complexity?",
        "The parameterised complexity of counting connected subgraphs and graph motifs",
        "Some hard families of parameterized counting problems",
        "The parameterised complexity of counting even and odd induced subgraphs",
        "Boolean Function Complexity - Advances and Frontiers, volume 27 of Algorithms and combinatorics",
        "The Weisfeiler-Leman algorithm: an exploration of its power",
        "Lower bound of the Hadwiger number of graphs by their average degree",
        "On the power of the Weisfeiler-Leman test for graph motif parameters",
        "Large networks and graph limits, volume 60 of American Mathematical Society Colloquium Publications",
        "Network motifs: Simple building blocks of complex networks",
        "Perceptrons - an introduction to computational geometry",
        "Weisfeiler and Leman go machine learning: the story so far",
        "Homomorphism-distinguishing closedness for graphs of bounded tree-width",
        "On the degree of boolean functions as real polynomials",
        "Analysis of Boolean functions",
        "Excluding induced subgraphs. III. A general asymptotic.",
        "On recognizing graph properties from adjacency matrices",
        "Graph minors. v. excluding a planar graph",
        "Counting problems on quantum graphs",
        "Counting induced subgraphs: A topological approach to #W[1]-hardness",
        "Counting small induced subgraphs satisfying monotone properties",
        "Detecting and counting small subgraphs, and evaluating a parameterized tutte polynomial: Lower bounds via toroidal grids and cayley graph expanders",
        "The complexity of computing the permanent",
        "Polynomials with two values",
        "Finding four-node subgraphs in triangle time"
    ],
    "reasoning": "Selected these 49 references because they represent foundational work and recent advances in Counting Small Induced Subgraphs: Hardness via Fourier Analysis Funded by the European Union (ERC, CountHom, 101077083). Views and opinions expressed are however those of the author(s) only and do not necessarily reflect those of the European Union or the European Research Council Executive Agency. Neither the European Union nor the granting authority can be held responsible for them., providing essential background knowledge and methodological foundations relevant to this research."
}
